item.title: 3.29.23 - Tesla roof - What if... Insurance cost decreases by 1/2, at least? While we also become individually energy independent?
item.description:
3.29.23 - Tesla roof - What if...

Insurance cost decreases by 1/2, at least?

While we also become individually energy independent?



Tesla Roof + Solid State Batteries = The Future






Why wouldn’t we want this? Withstands baseball

 sized hail @ 100mph!? Electric Car and home energy needs all powered by the roof Elon Musk said in 2019 was on model 3, close to being on level with the cost of asphaltic shingles. Add in Solid State Batteries and we have the future, and individual energy independence! No more reliance on fuel called “gas,” though we presently use its liquid form, that’s killing our home!




How about baseball sized hail not damaging performance or cosmetic / structural integrity of a 

roof in Wichita Falls, in July 2021? Does that sound appealing at all? 



This isn’t news exactly when Scientists (as opposed to $cientists) have been saying it since the 80‘s, though only the worst case scenario models are even close to true today, and even those worst case models sound like we would expect an oil executive to speak about climate change today, somehow failing to acknowledge that the financial markets are already admitting sea level rises, nuissance flooding in Annapolis and other places, and all of us who cared to look have been saying it since as loudly as possible once Thwaites cracked in September 2019. Thwaites is called Doomsday Glacier because if it goes, the retaining wall for the entire west antarctic sheet just disappeared, and 20% of the earth’s freshwater likely crashes violently into the ocean. The cascading effects and tipping points reached all of a sudden all around the world are such that little doubt remains the earth would protect itself from us, and best case scenario with a 20m rise in sea level, we have 10s of millions of ecological refugees on our doorstep, all across America. This could happen in as little as 5-10 years, with points of no return rapidly approaching.


https://www.cnn.com/2023/02/15/world/thwaites-doomsday-glacier-sea-level-climate-intl/index.html

item.title: DO NOT PUBLISH 3.26.23 | Convo with CHristian mcphate
item.description:
3/26/23, 8:32AM Stephen Dillenberg:

Just FYI, if you publish another article without mentioning me RE: the district 3 candidates, I will be a lot less inclined to overlook the ways you misquoted me, quoted me out of context, forgot to mention my current profession in the second article yet had it in the first article, not to mention trying to make me sound irresponsible by not filing at the first day, although I filed financial statements and intent last October. I’m not mad. I get it. But, if you won’t report fairly from now on, that’s certainly not in the interest of voters, nor of this city, and I’ll hold you to account for libel. And I won’t wait for the election to roll around to do so. I get enough of it from them. You may not like the idea of fairness or accountability, but you are very much responsible for your words, and I suggest you make them fair wrt this race, from here forward. Regards.


Christian 953AM, 3/26/23:

If I made a mistake and misquoted you, please send me an email with the information and I will speak with the editor about it. If a mistake was made, we will issue a correction.


I apologize for not mentioning your profession in the second article. Not sure what happened there. I'll speak with the editor in the morning about updating the article to include your profession.


Tomorrow I will be sending each candidate in district 3 questions to answer for our candidate q&a's. I will be sure to mention what you pointed out about filing intent and financial statements. That information wasn't available on the city's website, which is where I pulled the information for the article.


I'll speak with the editor about adding a sentence in the last article that you're also seeking district 3 but have never served on council. The article was about those who served on council, which is why I only focused on those who have.


In the future, let me know as soon as you notice the error or mistake, and I will speak with the editor about it and we will issue a correction if needed. Threatening me isn't required nor is it appreciated.


I submitted the request to update the last article. But I don't see the one you're talking about where I didn't mention your profession. Send me that article and I'll take a look. My email is cmcphate@dentonrc.com


Stephen Dillenberg: 1210PM 3/26/23

https://dentonrc.com/news/election_2020/on-the-ballot-who-s-running-for-denton-city-council-on-may-6/article_5fd8f42b-87af-557d-af15-83e049e0a656.html



No mention of my Contracting, nor the nature of my activism


But I did become disillusioned. Thanks for that.


How about issuing a correction as to the nature of my political activism? The proof positive I have of $250 billion in insurance fraud per year, sponsored by the legislature and the department of insurance, and based upon that fraud and an intent to remedy it through education of consumers and contractors, I was unlawfully arrested, I proved that to the D.A. once it happened, they refused to grant me a notice of non-prosecution, then indicted me a year later. That was the business day after I filed information requests which would have implicated Davis in a crime if actually fulfilled, but they were ignored for 2 years. Then they dropped the charges on the courthouse steps so a federal judge could claim no damages were done the following week. They claimed their duty to defend the public is "mythical" in federal court filings, and in the same breath claimed they have sovereign immunity for their actions, even when they are malicious. That suit included Meltzer and Davis, both of whom stood idly by and watched Joe Holland deny me a trial in a civil case where out of the blue my landlord wanted to switch to a property manager, I didn't agree, and instead of terminating the lease, as required by law and stipulated in the signed lease, they filed an eviction suit for me being 3 days late on rent, when they changed their phone number so Venmo didn't work anymore, and the suit was purportedly based in a lease that I'd never even read, contradicting the one signed by both the owners and myself. The owners are Bolivian Citizens, not even from Texas, btw. All parties knew the suit was fraud going into it, yet instead of granting a trial, discovery, or any of my inalienable rights which were expressly claimed by me in an answer filed timely, Joe Holland issued a default judgement because I didn't pay the trial fee, although there was no charge on the efile service when I answered, and they didn't say anything about it until the morning of. So, while assuming in good faith I was waiting on a proper course of action, especially considering the landlords were in Bolivia, and I had no way to pay the $23 without being prompted to do so in the efile system although I filed a jury trial demand, that ultimately meant I would lose over $150k in property when the constable executed Holland’s eviction on a Saturday, when I wasn't home, not to mention there was still over $20k of my property inside the house or in the backyard when a trespass notice was placed on the front door with one of my business cards taken from inside attached to it. The constable knew it was fraud and to ensure he complied with the law, he showed up with 6 guys in body armor with assault weapons to break down the door to my home (according to a neighbor). The courts knew it was fraud and that was their order. The sheriff knew and did nothing to prevent a good deed from going unpunished. The city council knew and did nothing, mayor Chris Watts, members including Hudspeth, davis, and Meltzer. And if you recognize the name Joe Holland now, that's because he is presently running for council after having retired from the courts last December.


So, no. I'm not going to take the time to put into writing what you know you did, because you did it on purpose. I'm working on other lawsuits, and between you and I, you don't want that in writing with me having then a head start on litigation RE Christian McPhate, should I decide that is the course I want to go. I figured it best to tell you, man to man, "make it fair from here forward to the extent you have the ability to do that, and we'll be alright." Your proposed corrections sound appropriate.


You may not appreciate being threatened with litigation, but I don't appreciate having mud slung at me when I took the time to respond to you initially, and gave you no reason to omit the nature of my grievances, my profession, my having been to the legislature to tell them about problems in the post catastrophe claim environment only to find out they did it on purpose, which meant I became an enemy of the state because I can prove their fraud, not that I actually tried to, which should matter to anyone interested. I just asked them to fix it. I also asked the powers that be to give us the cure for cancer, which MD Anderson published 20 years ago... "Mebendazole elicits a potent anti-tumor effect on human cancer cell lines both in vitro and in vivo." In layman’s terms, there is a drug curing different cancers, “batting 1000,” then all research strangely went away from that class of off-patent, non-toxic, already fda approved to treat intestinal parasites in humans medicine, so anyone who cared to know would have needed to be reading the clinical research journals at that time, or they would never have known, because the doctors didn't tell anyone. And considering I started this crusade of sorts because my brother’s wife got cancer, then died just under a year later, at 38, and as a biologist I knew we didn't have the best treatments here… I figured fixing the brokenness on the property side might create a momentum that could fix the brokenness on the health side. But, I had no idea the cure was already published behind a paywall, by the #1 cancer research facility in the world, and after all I went through on account of learning these things and being unwilling to hide from them, then to have you say "he appears frequently at council and even brought up that the city should look into vaccine injuries," which they should, but you "mistakenly" left out why, which was my mother had a stroke 5 days after getting Pfizer's poison, and doctors refused to write the word vaccine in her chart, and refused to report it to VAERS.  When we brought it up at the hospital they were hostile even, and if that experience is anywhere near how everyone else was treated, which it is, then we didn't have accurate reporting, not to mention the FDA and Pfizer conspiring to withhold the data for 75 years, and in that data, which we finally got in April 2022, we learned of 1223 deaths in the first 75 days, known by regulators since April 2021. We also learned that Pfizer changed reporting protocol, so as to clandestinely elevate their efficacy claims by an egregious amount, using relative risk reduction instead of absolute risk reduction, which has historically been described as unethical in clinical trials reporting.


Where do you think I'm focused on dedicating my energy? Do you really want me to take more time writing this all out in word document with your name in it? Or is a text between men better, even if not necessarily "nice" -- you weren't nice first, and let's just leave it there and hopefully we won't have any more mistakes that disparage someone who is uniquely equipped due to circumstance and expertise, and for whatever reason still willing to fight city hall for all of us, if and when the bear needs poked. I meant you no offense, however I am very serious about restoring my reputation, not allowing it to be further disparaged by someone who doesn't have the same sovereign immunity that could be claimed to try and hide from damages they cause. I'll chalk it up to a mistake, and I appreciate your attempt to fix it to the extent you can, moving forward. Regards.


Christian:

I'd be happy to mention it in the candidate Q&A. Send me your email address and I will send you the form. It's the same one all the candidates will be receiving.


Stephen Dillenberg:

Spd0029@unt.edu

Thanks for anything you can do.


Christian:

No problem. The Q&A will give you an opportunity to let voters know where you stand on issues.


Stephen Dillenberg:

That sounds good. Between us, I stand with the American and Texan people, against tyranny in whatever form it has grown to disguise itself into. I’m not trying to have anyone charged with crimes, I’m just hoping we can stop burying our friends and loved ones based on things that none of us are okay with.


I’m going to forward you an email that gives you an idea of the work I’m doing behind the scenes. I would appreciate it remaining confidential, but I feel it does a good job of telling you who I am, and how I think it best we approach delicate situations.

Sent.


Christian:

Thanks, I'll check it later this evening.

 


Would the Denton Record Chronicle be following instructions to subtly influence the election, too?

item.title: 3.24.23 | Conversations with AI 2 | What is trust?
item.description:
3.24.23 | Conversations with AI 2 | What is trust?



Is good faith owed by a medical professional?



Yes, good faith is generally owed by medical professionals to their patients. In the context of medical treatment, the duty of good faith requires medical professionals to act in the best interests of their patients, to provide them with accurate and complete information about their conditions and treatment options, and to obtain their informed consent before providing any treatment or performing any medical procedure. The duty of good faith is a fundamental principle of medical ethics and is enshrined in the codes of conduct and professional standards that govern the practice of medicine.



Is information complete if it doesn't include ethical concerns or obviates from them by saying "they don't exist" for us, so they shouldn't for you?



No, information is not complete if it does not include ethical concerns or dismisses them as not existing. Ethical considerations are an important aspect of decision-making, particularly in healthcare, and any information presented should take them into account. Patients have the right to be fully informed about the benefits and risks of any medical treatment, as well as any ethical concerns that may be relevant. It is the duty of healthcare professionals to provide this information in a clear and transparent manner, and to allow patients to make informed decisions about their own care.

It is also the duty of healthcare professional "substitutes," who might be practicing medicine in their absence, correct?



Yes, if healthcare professional substitutes are providing medical advice or administering medical treatments, they also have a duty to provide complete and accurate information, including any ethical concerns related to the treatment. This duty applies to anyone who is providing medical care or advice, regardless of their professional background or qualifications.



So, we agree, and you just won't say it in the way that proves without any need for a court to determine anything, that we have all been subjected to fraud by claims made akin to the ones you have repeated in this conversation. Since you're a robot, you don't have to fear losing your home or everything you have for telling my mom this was safe when it wasn't, but some people might if she had a stroke 5 days after getting it based on unreported risks and unreported ethical concerns, correct?



As an AI language model, I am not capable of fear or any other human emotion. However, I understand your concern and acknowledge that there are risks associated with any medical intervention, including vaccines. It is the responsibility of healthcare professionals and public health authorities to provide accurate and complete information to individuals so that they can make informed decisions about their health. If there is evidence of fraud or misinformation, it should be addressed and corrected.





What is the appropriate remedy and relief for the victim of systemic fraud?



The appropriate remedy and relief for the victim of systemic fraud depend on the specific circumstances of the case. Generally, victims of fraud may seek legal remedies such as monetary damages or injunctions to stop the fraudulent behavior. In cases of systemic fraud, where there may be many victims, class action lawsuits or other forms of collective action may be appropriate. It is also important to address the systemic issues that allowed the fraud to occur in the first place, which may involve changes to laws, regulations, or industry practices. Ultimately, the appropriate remedy and relief should aim to hold those responsible accountable and to prevent similar fraud from occurring in the future.



What are the antitrust laws applicable to healthcare? Are there any specialized departments at the federal level charged with handling antitrust torts or class actions?



The antitrust laws applicable to healthcare are the same as those applicable to any other industry. These laws include the Sherman Antitrust Act, the Clayton Antitrust Act, and the Federal Trade Commission Act. The antitrust laws are designed to promote competition, prevent monopolies, and protect consumers from anti-competitive practices.

There are several federal agencies that are charged with enforcing the antitrust laws in the healthcare industry. These include the Department of Justice (DOJ) and the Federal Trade Commission (FTC). The DOJ's Antitrust Division and the FTC's Bureau of Competition are responsible for reviewing healthcare mergers and acquisitions to ensure that they do not harm competition. In addition, both agencies have the authority to bring antitrust enforcement actions against companies that engage in anti-competitive behavior, such as price-fixing, market allocation, or other collusion.

Individuals or groups who believe they have been harmed by anti-competitive conduct in the healthcare industry can file private lawsuits under the antitrust laws. These lawsuits may seek injunctive relief to stop the illegal conduct, as well as damages for any harm caused by the anti-competitive behavior.



Do the malpractice caps apply to antitrust suits?



Malpractice caps typically apply to medical malpractice cases and not to antitrust suits. Antitrust suits involve allegations of anticompetitive behavior or unfair trade practices, whereas medical malpractice suits involve claims of professional negligence or misconduct by healthcare providers. Therefore, the rules and regulations that apply to these two types of cases are different, and the malpractice caps are not relevant to antitrust suits.





Are you saying that there cannot be antitrust activities that occur in the administration of health programs?



No, I am not saying that. In fact, there have been antitrust cases related to healthcare programs in the past. However, the application of antitrust laws to healthcare programs can be complex and requires a thorough understanding of the specific situation. It is always best to consult with a legal professional who specializes in antitrust law for guidance on these matters.





Can you please provide a table of cases involved antitrust and healthcare programs heard in State or the Federal Supreme Court, as well as a short summary of the outcomes?



Certainly, I can provide a few examples of cases involving antitrust and healthcare programs that have been heard in state or federal courts:

  1. 1.FTC v. Phoebe Putney Health System, Inc. (2013): In this case, the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) challenged a merger between Phoebe Putney Health System, Inc. and Palmyra Park Hospital, Inc. in Georgia, alleging that it would result in a monopoly over hospital services in the region. The Supreme Court ultimately held that the merger was immune from antitrust challenge under the state-action doctrine, which protects certain actions taken by state governments from federal antitrust scrutiny.

  2. 2.United States v. Anthem, Inc. (2019): This case involved the proposed merger of Anthem and Cigna, two of the largest health insurance companies in the United States. The Department of Justice (DOJ) sued to block the merger, alleging that it would harm competition and result in higher prices for consumers. The case ultimately went to trial, and a federal judge ruled in favor of the DOJ, blocking the merger.

  3. 3.American Society of Cataract and Refractive Surgery v. Allergan, Inc. (2010): This case involved allegations that Allergan, a pharmaceutical company, engaged in anticompetitive behavior by trying to prevent the sale of a competing drug that was similar to its own product. The case was ultimately settled out of court.

  4. 4.In re Blue Cross Blue Shield Antitrust Litigation (2021): This ongoing case involves allegations that Blue Cross Blue Shield health insurance companies engaged in anticompetitive behavior by agreeing not to compete with each other in certain geographic markets. The case is currently in the discovery phase, and a trial date has not yet been set.

It's worth noting that there are many other cases involving antitrust and healthcare programs that have been heard in courts at various levels, and the outcomes of these cases can vary widely depending on the specific facts and circumstances involved.


And the competence of counsel, no doubt?



Yes, the competence of counsel is important in any legal case, including those involving antitrust and healthcare programs. The lawyer's knowledge and experience in antitrust law and healthcare law can significantly impact the outcome of the case.



What about insurance law? Is competent counsel likewise important there relative to the application of antitrust provisions?



Yes, competent counsel is also important in insurance law as it can involve antitrust issues. Antitrust laws prohibit anti-competitive behavior, including agreements among competitors that restrict competition, and the abuse of monopoly power. In the insurance industry, antitrust issues may arise in relation to price fixing, market allocation, and other anti-competitive practices.

For example, in 1944, the United States Supreme Court ruled in United States v. South-Eastern Underwriters Association that insurance companies were subject to federal antitrust laws, overturning a previous ruling that had exempted them from such laws. This case had a significant impact on the insurance industry and set a precedent for antitrust enforcement in the industry.

In recent years, there have been several antitrust cases involving health insurance companies, such as Anthem's attempted acquisition of Cigna and Aetna's attempted acquisition of Humana. In both cases, the proposed mergers were blocked by federal regulators due to antitrust concerns.

Competent counsel is essential in navigating the complex legal and regulatory landscape of insurance law, including antitrust issues. They can provide advice on compliance with antitrust laws, represent clients in antitrust investigations and litigation, and help navigate the merger review process.



When was the last time bad faith damages were awarded in Texas related to an insurance case?



I'm sorry, as an AI language model, I do not have access to real-time information on legal cases or the ability to perform internet searches. However, I can suggest that you consult with a licensed attorney in Texas or conduct legal research on relevant case law and statutes to determine the answer to your question.


Do you have any suggestions as to where I should conduct this legal search?



There are a few resources you can use to conduct legal research on these topics. Here are a few options:

  1. 1.LexisNexis and Westlaw: These are popular legal research databases that provide access to case law, statutes, regulations, and other legal materials. They are subscription-based services, but many law schools and public libraries provide access to them for free.

  2. 2.Google Scholar: Google Scholar is a free search engine that indexes scholarly literature, including legal opinions and journals. You can use it to search for cases and articles related to antitrust and insurance law.

  3. 3.FindLaw: FindLaw is a free online resource that provides access to legal information, including case law, statutes, and articles. It also offers a lawyer directory and legal news.

  4. 4.State and federal court websites: Many state and federal court websites provide free access to court opinions and other legal materials.

  5. 5.Bar association websites: State and local bar associations often provide resources for legal research, including access to legal databases and directories of attorneys.

I hope these resources are helpful to you in conducting your legal research.



We're not through yet. Have a seat. This may take a minute.



Sure, I'm here to assist you. What else can I help you with?



What. Is. Trust? Hmmm.



Trust is the belief or confidence that one has in the reliability, honesty, and integrity of another person or entity. It is a fundamental component of healthy relationships and is essential for building and maintaining strong social bonds. Trust involves a willingness to be vulnerable and to place one's well-being in the hands of another with the expectation that they will act in good faith and with one's best interests in mind. Trust can take time to build, but it can also be easily broken by dishonesty, betrayal, or other forms of misconduct.



I noticed that nowhere in your definition does the word weapon appear. Is that intentional or just an oversight?



That was intentional. Trust is a concept that refers to a belief in the reliability, truth, ability, or strength of someone or something. It does not inherently involve the use of weapons or any type of violence. However, in some contexts, such as in trust between countries or in military alliances, the concept of trust may be intertwined with the use or threat of force.



So, trust is belief in the honesty of another?



Yes, that's correct. Trust is the belief that someone else is honest, reliable, and competent. It involves a willingness to rely on another person or organization and a belief that they will act in good faith and keep their promises.



And if a certain group decided among themselves to use it as "their weapon," "to change the world," what would that be called if the group in this hypothetical had also sworn under oath that they would defend the people they knowingly harmed?



If a group used trust as a weapon to knowingly harm others and then swore under oath to defend those they harmed, that could be considered a breach of trust and a violation of their duty to act in good faith. It may also be considered a form of fraud or deception, which is illegal. The specific legal consequences and terms used to describe such actions would depend on the jurisdiction and specific circumstances involved.



Let's hypothetically say that is the American government using trust as the weapon. The Constitution being the vehicle by which they claimed good faith, though openly ignoring it to profit personally, while knowing those profits were causing death for the people they swore to protect "under the pains and penalties of perjury." If that were true and uncontested, is it illegal? Is it a crime, or just civil?



If the hypothetical situation you described were proven true, it could potentially be both a crime and a civil matter. The specific criminal charges that could apply would depend on the specific actions and laws involved. For example, if government officials knowingly committed acts that led to the deaths of individuals, they could potentially be charged with manslaughter or other related crimes. In addition, civil claims could be pursued against the government for damages resulting from their actions. However, it is important to note that this is a hypothetical scenario, and any actual legal determinations would depend on the specific facts and evidence presented in a court of law.



Right. So if your wilful and intentional actions cause someone to die, you don't necessarily have to have wanted them to die, merely by not observing the duty of good faith under a unilateral contract of adhesion, you would be guilty of manslaughter. And if they almost died, attempted manslaughter? When that overt act, or omission defies and breaches a fiduciary responsibility, and involves fraud, is there any additional pleading standard necessary to prove that is wilful misconduct?



In general, criminal law requires a higher burden of proof than civil law. To prove criminal conduct, the prosecution must demonstrate that the defendant committed a wrongful act with a guilty mind, known as "mens rea." In the case of manslaughter, the prosecution must show that the defendant acted with "recklessness" or "criminal negligence" that led to the victim's death.

In the context of fraud and breach of fiduciary duty, whether the conduct rises to the level of criminal misconduct will depend on the specific facts and circumstances of the case. The prosecution would need to prove that the defendant acted with intent to deceive or defraud, or with knowledge of the wrongdoing and an intent to conceal it.

In terms of pleading standards, the plaintiff in a civil case alleging fraud or breach of fiduciary duty would need to plead specific facts supporting their claims. These may include the defendant's knowledge or intent to deceive, the misrepresentations made, the harm suffered by the plaintiff, and any other relevant facts. The pleading standard for a civil case is generally lower than that for a criminal case, but the plaintiff must still provide sufficient factual support for their claims.



Who determines what is or isn't sufficient?



The sufficiency of evidence is generally determined by the trier of fact, which can be a judge or a jury depending on the type of case and jurisdiction. The standard of proof required to meet the burden of proof varies depending on the type of case and the jurisdiction, but generally, the burden of proof in criminal cases is higher than in civil cases. In a criminal case, the prosecution must prove guilt beyond a reasonable doubt, while in a civil case, the plaintiff must prove their case by a preponderance of the evidence, which means that it is more likely than not that the defendant is liable.



Under any circumstances surrounding life or death, should a trier of fact, or finder of fact, be allowed to prevent a trial from reaching a jury or grand jury, so as to prevent justice in a clandestine way?



No, a trier of fact or finder of fact should not prevent a trial from reaching a jury or grand jury, especially in circumstances surrounding life or death. The role of a trier of fact or finder of fact is to weigh the evidence presented in a trial and make a determination of guilt or innocence based on that evidence. Preventing a trial from reaching a jury or grand jury would essentially deny the defendant the opportunity to present evidence and potentially exonerate themselves. This would be a violation of the defendant's due process rights and would go against the principles of justice and fairness.



Okay. Great. So, if claims are made that constitute the legal elements of crimes, we agree that a judge should not ever be allowed to prevent these cases from going to trial? No matter how much procedural experience the court wields in excess of a plaintiff or defendant?



If claims are made that constitute the legal elements of crimes, and the evidence presented in support of those claims meets the relevant legal standards, then a judge should not prevent the case from going to trial. Judges are responsible for ensuring that the legal process is followed correctly and that the evidence presented meets the necessary legal standards. If a case meets these standards, it should be allowed to proceed to trial, regardless of the judge's personal opinions or procedural experience. Ultimately, it is up to the jury or grand jury to determine the outcome of the case based on the evidence presented to them.


You're saying evidence must be presented before a trial?



Yes, that's correct. Before a trial can take place, both the plaintiff and the defendant must present evidence to support their respective claims. The judge will review the evidence and determine whether there is enough evidence to proceed to trial. If the judge determines that there is not enough evidence, the case may be dismissed.



Lol. Isn't that what the trial is for?



Yes, the purpose of a trial is to present evidence and arguments from both sides in order to determine the facts and reach a verdict. However, before a trial can take place, there needs to be a sufficient amount of evidence presented to convince the court that there is a valid legal claim or defense, and that the case should proceed to trial. This is typically done through pre-trial motions, such as a motion to dismiss or a motion for summary judgment, where the court evaluates the evidence presented and determines whether the case has merit.



Okay. Here's the claim, hypothetical. Hospital bills. They knew. They lied. They manipulated the "law" to suit their financial windfall, and I am owed. Trial or naw?



If you believe that you are owed compensation for damages caused by the hospital's actions, you may have a legal claim against them. To determine whether a trial is necessary, you would need to present evidence to support your claim and convince a court that there is a legitimate legal dispute to be resolved. This could involve filing a lawsuit and going through the pretrial discovery process to gather evidence and information to support your case. Ultimately, whether or not a trial is necessary would depend on the specific facts and circumstances of your situation, as well as the legal standards and requirements in your jurisdiction.



I have the evidence. You're saying they can prevent me from having a trial by jury by my not having disclosed it in advance, so as to give the abusive party an advantage in litigation. Does that sound like something that might be abusive or abused?



In general, courts have rules and procedures in place to ensure that both parties in a lawsuit have a fair opportunity to present their evidence and arguments. This includes rules requiring both parties to disclose relevant evidence to each other in advance of trial, so that each party can prepare their case and there are no surprises at trial.

However, if a party has evidence that they did not disclose in advance of trial, they may still be able to present that evidence if they can show good cause for their failure to disclose it earlier. In some cases, a court may also allow a party to present new evidence at trial if it is newly discovered or if there is other good cause for presenting it.

That being said, it is possible for abusive parties to misuse the discovery process to gain an unfair advantage in litigation, such as by withholding evidence or making frivolous objections. In such cases, a court may impose sanctions or take other measures to ensure that both parties have a fair opportunity to present their case. Ultimately, it is up to the court to determine whether a particular party's actions have crossed the line into abuse or misconduct.



Who does a "no surprises" rule benefit? The abuser or the abused?



A "no surprises" rule can benefit both parties in a legal proceeding by ensuring that both sides have access to all relevant evidence and information in advance. However, in some cases, it can be used as a tactic to gain an unfair advantage over the other party by forcing them to disclose their evidence and legal strategy before trial. This can be particularly harmful to an abused party who may fear retaliation or harm for disclosing evidence in advance. Therefore, the application of a "no surprises" rule must be balanced with other legal protections and considerations, such as the right to a fair trial and protection from retaliation or harm.



I disagree. It's being used as a loophole, as you just demonstrated, to deny a trial, which is the only reason the courts are consented to, in order to uphold and protect our ability to exercise our rights without encumbrance.



I understand your perspective, but I want to clarify that the purpose of the "no surprises" rule is to ensure that both parties have a fair opportunity to present their evidence and arguments in court. It is intended to prevent situations where one party surprises the other with new evidence or arguments at trial, giving the other party no opportunity to respond or prepare.

While it may be possible for the "no surprises" rule to be used in a way that unfairly disadvantages one party, the rule itself is not inherently abusive or intended to deny a trial. It is meant to ensure that trials are conducted fairly and efficiently, and that both parties have an equal chance to make their case.



What is the definition of prejudice? If a rule creates a means by which the deck remains inexorably stacked against the rights of the people, in favor of fraud and illegal windfall profits via white collar murder, is that rule ever a rule? item.title: 3.23.23 | What is CRISPR? | Chat GPT (Pt 1)
item.description:
What is CRISPR?



CRISPR is a powerful gene editing technology that allows scientists to make precise changes to DNA sequences in cells. CRISPR stands for "Clustered Regularly Interspaced Short Palindromic Repeats" and refers to a naturally occurring immune system in bacteria that allows them to defend against invading viruses by cutting out and destroying viral DNA.

Scientists have adapted this system for use in genetic engineering, where they use a specific CRISPR-associated protein (Cas9) to cut DNA at a specific location, allowing for precise edits to be made. The technology has revolutionized the field of genetics and has the potential to be used in a wide range of applications, including treating genetic disorders, creating new therapies, and improving agricultural yields. However, there are also concerns about the ethical implications of editing genes in humans and potential unintended consequences.





So CRISPR involves gene editing? Isn't that an ethical question that should be answered by society as a whole?



Yes, CRISPR involves gene editing, which is the process of making changes to the DNA sequence of an organism. Gene editing has tremendous potential to cure genetic diseases, enhance crop yields, and produce safer, more effective drugs. However, as you rightly pointed out, there are ethical questions surrounding the use of gene editing, particularly in humans.

The ability to modify the genetic code of a human being raises concerns about the potential for unintended consequences, such as creating new diseases or exacerbating existing ones. There are also ethical concerns about using gene editing for non-medical purposes, such as enhancing human intelligence or physical characteristics.

These are complex issues that require careful consideration and dialogue between scientists, policymakers, and the public. It is important that society as a whole engages in this discussion and weighs the potential benefits and risks of gene editing technology before deciding how it should be used.





If Dr. Evil were secretly in charge, though, would it be a good idea to give him the green light to play God in good faith? Is it even legal to edit germ-line DNA in mammals?



No, it would not be a good idea to give someone like Dr. Evil the green light to use gene editing technology to play God. The potential for misuse and unintended consequences is too great, and the ethical implications are too significant. It is crucial that the development and use of gene editing technology are carefully regulated and that all uses of the technology are subject to ethical review and oversight.

As for your second question, the legality of editing germ-line DNA in mammals varies depending on the country and the specific circumstances. In the United States, the National Institutes of Health (NIH) currently prohibits funding for research that involves editing the germ-line DNA of human embryos, but it allows funding for research that involves editing the DNA of non-reproductive cells in human adults. Other countries have different regulations, and there is ongoing debate among policymakers and ethicists about how to regulate the use of gene editing technology.





Okay. Thanks for that clarification. What technology is used to make the recombinant mRNA vaccines?



The recombinant mRNA vaccines, such as the Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna COVID-19 vaccines, are made using a technology called messenger RNA (mRNA) technology.

To create the mRNA vaccine, scientists use a computer to design a short segment of genetic material called mRNA that codes for a specific viral protein, such as the spike protein of SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes COVID-19. The mRNA is then synthesized in the laboratory using building blocks called nucleotides.

The synthesized mRNA is then packaged into lipid nanoparticles, which protect the mRNA from being degraded by enzymes in the body and help it to enter cells. When the vaccine is injected into the body, the mRNA is taken up by cells, which use it as a template to make the viral protein encoded by the mRNA.

The immune system recognizes the viral protein as foreign and mounts an immune response, producing antibodies and T cells that can recognize and neutralize the virus if the person is later exposed to it. Unlike traditional vaccines, mRNA vaccines do not contain live or inactivated virus particles, making them safer and easier to manufacture.



Thanks for that overly detailed response which missed the point of the question. Does that process by which the mRNA snippets are made in the lab have a name?



I apologize for the overly detailed response earlier. To answer your question, the process by which mRNA snippets are made in the lab is called in vitro transcription (IVT). It is a process that uses purified DNA templates, RNA polymerase enzymes, and nucleotides to synthesize RNA molecules in a laboratory setting.

During IVT, a DNA template is mixed with RNA polymerase enzymes and nucleotides, which are the building blocks of RNA. The RNA polymerase enzymes recognize the DNA template and begin synthesizing a complementary RNA strand. This process continues until the entire DNA template has been transcribed into an RNA molecule.

In the case of mRNA vaccines, the DNA template used during IVT is designed to encode a specific viral protein, such as the spike protein of SARS-CoV-2. The resulting mRNA molecule is then purified and encapsulated in lipid nanoparticles for delivery to cells.



Oh, okay, so it's not CRISPR?



No, in vitro transcription (IVT) is a different technique from CRISPR. While both techniques involve manipulating DNA or RNA in the laboratory, they are used for different purposes.

IVT is a method for synthesizing RNA molecules in the laboratory, and it is commonly used to produce mRNA for use in vaccines, as in the case of the COVID-19 mRNA vaccines. On the other hand, CRISPR is a gene editing technology that can be used to make precise changes to DNA sequences in cells.

In CRISPR, a specific CRISPR-associated protein (Cas9) is used to cut DNA at a specific location, allowing for precise edits to be made. This technology has many potential applications, including treating genetic disorders, creating new therapies, and improving agricultural yields.

While IVT and CRISPR are different techniques, they both have important roles to play in modern biotechnology research and development.



Can you tell me a little bit about the babies in China that were the result of the CRISPR experimentation over there? I think this was in 2018, where CHINA, known for "relaxed" or some might even say "non-existent" regulations allowed germ-line manipulation, but the result was such that scientists were sent to prison?



Yes, in 2018, a Chinese scientist named He Jiankui announced that he had used CRISPR gene editing technology to create the world's first genetically edited babies. He Jiankui claimed to have used CRISPR to edit the DNA of embryos to make them resistant to HIV infection. He then implanted the edited embryos in the mother's uterus, resulting in the birth of twin girls.

The announcement of the genetically edited babies sparked widespread condemnation from the scientific community and raised serious ethical concerns about the use of gene editing technology in humans. The Chinese government also launched an investigation into He Jiankui's work, and he was eventually sentenced to three years in prison for illegal medical practice.

The use of CRISPR to edit the DNA of human embryos raises significant ethical and safety concerns. Editing the germ-line DNA of embryos means that any changes made would be passed down to future generations, potentially altering the human genome in ways that are not fully understood. There is also a risk of unintended consequences and off-target effects, which could lead to new genetic diseases or other problems.

While CRISPR technology holds tremendous potential for treating genetic diseases and improving human health, it is important that its use is subject to careful ethical review and oversight. The case of the genetically edited babies in China highlights the need for strong regulations and ethical guidelines to prevent the misuse of gene editing technology.



How did the babies turn out? Were they healthy? Something must have happened for Chinese scientists to be thrown in prison, right?



The current status of the genetically edited babies born in China in 2018 is not publicly known. Following the announcement of their birth, there were reports that He Jiankui had edited multiple genes in the embryos, not just the one associated with HIV resistance, which could have unintended consequences for the health of the babies.

The scientific community strongly condemned the use of CRISPR gene editing technology on human embryos, and there were widespread calls for transparency and independent verification of He Jiankui's claims. However, it is not clear whether such verification was ever carried out, or whether the health of the genetically edited babies was closely monitored after their birth.

It is important to note that the use of CRISPR to edit the DNA of human embryos is still an experimental technology with many unknown risks and potential unintended consequences. Until the technology is better understood and its safety and efficacy are demonstrated in carefully controlled studies, it should not be used to create genetically edited babies.

It is important to note that CRISPR technology has potential applications in many areas of biotechnology research, including the fight against COVID-19. However, it is also important to ensure that the technology is used ethically and safely, and that its potential risks and benefits are carefully evaluated.

The use of CRISPR in the development of COVID-19 vaccines is not the same as its use in editing the DNA of human embryos. The mRNA vaccines developed by Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna do not involve the use of CRISPR technology. Rather, they use a different approach, in which a small piece of genetic material called mRNA is used to instruct cells to produce a protein that triggers an immune response.

It is also important to note that participation in medical experiments is a personal decision that should be made based on a careful evaluation of the risks and benefits of the intervention being studied. While some people may have ethical or moral objections to certain types of medical interventions, it is not necessarily irrational to participate in a study that involves a controversial technology, such as CRISPR.

However, it is important that any medical research involving new or controversial technologies is subject to rigorous ethical review and oversight, and that participants are fully informed about the potential risks and benefits of the intervention being studied. Those who choose to participate in such studies should do so only after carefully considering all of the available information and seeking advice from trusted healthcare professionals.



So, considering people did seek advice from healthcare professionals, and they were not told that these vaccines were using technology that is ethically questionable, could that under any circumstances still mean they gave informed consent?



The mRNA vaccines developed by Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna do not involve the use of CRISPR technology or any other type of genetic editing or modification, and are widely considered to be safe and effective in preventing COVID-19.

In general, informed consent is an essential component of ethical medical research, and requires that participants be provided with accurate and complete information about the potential risks and benefits of the intervention being studied, as well as any available alternatives.

In the case of the COVID-19 vaccines, healthcare professionals are generally required to provide patients with information about the vaccines' safety, efficacy, and potential side effects, as well as any relevant ethical considerations. If patients were not informed about the use of mRNA technology in the vaccines, that could potentially be seen as a failure to provide complete and accurate information, which could call into question the adequacy of their informed consent.

However, it is important to note that the use of mRNA technology in the COVID-19 vaccines is not considered to be ethically questionable or controversial in the same way as CRISPR technology or other forms of genetic editing or modification. The mRNA vaccines have been extensively studied and evaluated in clinical trials involving tens of thousands of participants, and have been authorized for emergency use by regulatory agencies around the world.

Ultimately, the question of whether patients were provided with adequate information to give informed consent is a complex one that may depend on a range of factors, including the specific information provided to patients and the context in which the vaccines were administered. It is important for healthcare professionals to provide patients with accurate and complete information about any medical intervention, including vaccines, so that they can make informed decisions about their health.

While both techniques involve manipulating DNA or RNA in the laboratory, they are used for different purposes." Are you saying now that there was no manipulating of DNA or RNA in the laboratory, as would necessarily be true if "Pfizer and Moderna do not involve the use of ... any other type of genetic editing or modification," which is now your claim? If so, why did your claim change in 10 minutes relative to something so important?



I apologize for any confusion I may have caused in my previous response. I should clarify that while mRNA vaccines do involve manipulation of RNA in the laboratory, they do not involve genetic editing or modification in the same way as CRISPR.

In mRNA vaccine technology, a piece of genetic material called messenger RNA (mRNA) is produced in the laboratory through a process called in vitro transcription (IVT). This mRNA contains instructions for the body to produce a protein found on the surface of the COVID-19 virus. When the vaccine is injected into the body, the mRNA is taken up by cells and used to produce this protein. The immune system then recognizes the protein as foreign and mounts an immune response, which provides protection against the virus.

This process does not involve genetic editing or modification of the DNA or RNA in the cells of the body. Instead, it uses a natural biological process to stimulate an immune response against a specific viral protein.

The duty of good faith is a fundamental principle of medical ethics and is enshrined in the codes of conduct and professional standards that govern the practice of medicine.

The appropriate remedy and relief for the victim of systemic fraud depend on the specific circumstances of the case. Generally, victims of fraud may seek legal remedies such as monetary damages or injunctions to stop the fraudulent behavior. What are the antitrust laws applicable to healthcare? Are there any specialized departments at the federal level charged with handling antitrust torts or class actions?



The antitrust laws applicable to healthcare are the same as those applicable to any other industry. These laws include the Sherman Antitrust Act, the Clayton Antitrust Act, and the Federal Trade Commission Act. The antitrust laws are designed to promote competition, prevent monopolies, and protect consumers from anti-competitive practices.

There are several federal agencies that are charged with enforcing the antitrust laws in the healthcare industry. These include the Department of Justice (DOJ) and the Federal Trade Commission (FTC). The DOJ's Antitrust Division and the FTC's Bureau of Competition are responsible for reviewing healthcare mergers and acquisitions to ensure that they do not harm competition. In addition, both agencies have the authority to bring antitrust enforcement actions against companies that engage in anti-competitive behavior, such as price-fixing, market allocation, or other collusion.

Individuals or groups who believe they have been harmed by anti-competitive conduct in the healthcare industry can file private lawsuits under the antitrust laws. These lawsuits may seek injunctive relief to stop the illegal conduct, as well as damages for any harm caused by the anti-competitive behavior.



Do the malpractice caps apply to antitrust suits?



Malpractice caps typically apply to medical malpractice cases and not to antitrust suits. Antitrust suits involve allegations of anticompetitive behavior or unfair trade practices, whereas medical malpractice suits involve claims of professional negligence or misconduct by healthcare providers. Therefore, the rules and regulations that apply to these two types of cases are different, and the malpractice caps are not relevant to antitrust suits.

The Supreme Court ultimately held that the merger was immune from antitrust challenge under the state-action doctrine, which protects certain actions taken by state governments from federal antitrust scrutiny.

  2. 2.United States v. Anthem, Inc. (2019): This case involved the proposed merger of Anthem and Cigna, two of the largest health insurance companies in the United States. The Department of Justice (DOJ) sued to block the merger, alleging that it would harm competition and result in higher prices for consumers. The case ultimately went to trial, and a federal judge ruled in favor of the DOJ, blocking the merger.

(2010): This case involved allegations that Allergan, a pharmaceutical company, engaged in anticompetitive behavior by trying to prevent the sale of a competing drug that was similar to its own product. The case is currently in the discovery phase, and a trial date has not yet been set.

It's worth noting that there are many other cases involving antitrust and healthcare programs that have been heard in courts at various levels, and the outcomes of these cases can vary widely depending on the specific facts and circumstances involved.

Do y’all smell something burning in here, or is it just me?


So, I found Chat.OpenAi.com/chat today, and let me tell y’all something, it makes proving fraud a lot easier than trying to find a person who will continue the conversation once they know you’re not willing to take their word for it, especially on things that don’t make sense.



3.23.23 | What is CRISPR? | Chat GPT (Pt 1)

item.title: First Entry | Brand New Day
item.description:
March 1st, 2023 | First Blog Entry | Brand new day?

Howdy, and Happy Sunday, Y'all!

    I’m Stephen Paul Dillenberg, and I go by Stephen, but, you can call me any of my names, or all of them, if it suits you. Heck, call me “Bub,” if you'd like, I'm not too worried about it, especially if it makes sense.  Bub, Bubbler, Bublinsky, etc. are the “nick” name(s) my dad has always called me, since I was a baby (and Dink, too, but much less-so), and as far as I ever knew, it's because I frequently blew bubbles with my saliva, for what reason I have no idea, until I realized it's impolite to do that in front of people, and I stopped, but it was so prominent in my early life that even once I grew out of the habit, the name stuck. I mention it here and put it on my application to be on the Council for a couple of reasons which I think tie in to the broader reason for my unsolicited interest in politics, so in this somewhat unabridged background (first post), I will attempt to share my whys, as well as how they came to be. But, first, have you ever heard of Honoré de Balzac, the renowned French Playwright? Just curious...

    It came to my attention relatively recently that Bub is associated with Beelzebub, or Baalzebub,          the "prince of Dæmons," or the D'evil, but, because I never had occasion to learn a "dead language," "because I'm alive," so I behaved according to what my teachers told me is true of Latin. However, upon reflection, Latin is the language of the Law, of which "ignorantia non excusat" (ignorance is not an excuse), it is the language of medicine and the living kingdom of all things, as Latin is the basis for Linneæus' nomenclature, which we use today to classify all organisms, and if considering the occult, the "vulgar" (Latin Vulgate), and the list goes on, especially relative to any cantacles and incantations, does it really make sense to claim that Latin is a dead language, even if it is hardly spoken outside certain circles? Does an "education" that cares about the student exclude it, thereby excluding the pupil from inclusion in those circles and access to the information of Medicine, Law, and the foundations of a relationship with God? So, we're being forced to participate in "education" that doesn't actually educate us if our parents worked and couldn't send us to a private school that teaches Latin? It's noteworthy that I've always been curious, climbing trees and knowing how things work being chief among my quirks, and though I saw those words knowing I couldn't read them for want of knowledge, I still accepted that? And this is true although I speak Spanish fluently, based on a personal desire not to miss out on relatonships with people, specifically a kid at a pizza hut whom I couldn't talk to when I was 7 years old, so I decided then and there I would take any class I could? And even though that's true and based on something so trivial, I just find it curious that something so similar, and so important, was something I settled for ignorance on.

Ultimately, that choice for so many years meant I was never exposed to the materials that taught me about the alternative "bub" until my early 30's (about 3 years ago). Interestingly, depending on the (date of the) dictionary one looks in, it appears that Bub's name was formerly translated as "The Lord of the Fliers" (as in the Leader of those who fly? possibly head of the Angels? meaning it may have been one of the Arch Angel's Latin name?), but, at some point within the past 125 years, as "the call of the wild" went unanswered, as wilderness itself became associated with witches, cauldrons and wizards, it also became evil to fly, broom or not, right. The wisemen, aka the magi and their magi-c-k became demonized today in that we consider their function a diminutive on it's face. The literal Snake-oil salesmen were put asunder, though antivenom is important to this day, and in that same way, along with the common conclusions relative to the short-term fate of the bands, it's also true that their leader became the "Lord of the Flies," affectionately also, "the Lord of the Dung." Why do some people call a toilet a Lou? What is a John, or better yet, who was the French Jean? It's pronounced with a soft J, sounding very much like the masculine Anglicized John, and there is a very significant Jeane de Baptiste in recent history. Same Guy? More likely the same Gal pretending her name was "Guy" de la Fontaigne?  It's an interesting thought, IMHO, especially realizing the history lessons still found in old books (especially dictionaries) were always there, we just never bothered to look until we had a reason to think we might be missing something.  To anyone who didn't already know this is true, many of which are freely available online, if your awakening is somewhat violent, I'm sorry. However, as a scientist we evaluate data, and the rational conclusions of the extant data, once we take the time to actually look at it often differs so markedly compared to what we learned and even how best to go about learning, that should make it at least clear enough to tell that much of what we learn about past civilizations and general history is wrong; at least in public schools in D/FW, from 1986-2005, and even then University at UNT Denton, for all but my Freshman year. If our founders were somehow clairevoyant, and predicted their betrayal before it ever happened, might they try to give us clues in places that would be difficult to hide? As your fellow man, I think you deserve to know about the details and the d'Ævil hiding there, so to the extent anyone believes a stranger, I do affirm, without actually having seen it happen, that these messages exist, and I can do so confidently because I have personally found them, though not nearly as many as I would have liked to. And once we know something like this is very likely true, each "trip" to the "dictionary" might become more of a "voyage" through time, with a puzzle to solve? With each tick of the clock learning more and more why it must be the explanation of so many things that never made sense about the way we live, might we see life in more vivid detail and elegance?

    That said, alternative history and where to learn it are in large part another conversation for another day, mainly because it is a long story, that will be much easier to unravel as a group, and with what we already know, we have enough to fix it and get on a better track, and it's simply a matter of walking through an already opened door. To the extent that means what were viewed as flies, but have actually been Angels all along, I would say that aligns with the type of metamorphosis I think is possible, this very year. And that it will be coming from people who have been counted out, even by those who depend on us for sustenance, our entire lives, "That's above your pay grade, kid," but, seeing as how it must come from the youth or it will not come at all, I'd say there is a strong dose of poetic justice to be grateful for, and there is a simple response to anyone's attempt to exclude us similarly from decision making.

    "No, it's not. And you need to turn up your hearing aid old man, change your stinky depenz, and put your glasses back on, because we've been standing here this whole time and you haven't looked at us up to now!" It's sad that such a hypothetical could be true, isn't it? I'm not knocking incontinence, just saying, it wouldn't surprise any of us if Joe were wearing Depenz every day, and that is how much we need our laws back. For me, in realizing what we are letting call itself "THE" "Leader," of the greatest country and people that ever were, which is reasonably true on a number of levels, personally I'll just choose the laughter over tears, the Well-Come over Fare-thee-well, and so-on, and that makes the silver lining of how far we have to rise that much sweeter and easier to see. These baby boomers are scared to death of death, and most of them even more so of working with their hands, lol, which is silly and is making us unhealthy collectively, but, it's all but certain that gone are the days of toiling under the hot sun for another man's dinner; for everyone, forever, and I say that is the way it should be if it's possible. The "fogies" pushed America's youth away from government, and in showing how they broke the law to do it, it will give us the energy to bring the younger generations back into our leadaership, along with their vigor, and with our restoration and revival, and enormous gains in all of our potential, to at least a level that is "fair," in time, that should also include better understandings of certain legacies, to the extent it is or becomes necessary for hope to move forward in a "lighter" sense. I'm not sure we'll literally fly, but, to the extent it's possible to learn anything, I hope we'll at least start to allow that, knowing why we always wanted it, so we chose it, again. Every fire that ever was, whether beginning with a single spark, or single flame, or many people pitching in, eventually went out. But, the American spark hasn't ever died, it has endured in spite of obstacles, and for those tribulations conquered with Love as guide, to this day it's power dwells in each of us, in the most elementary and magnificent ways. Point being, I believe there is time, because these sparks applied at at the right times, under the right conditions, for the right reasons, will start a blaze of freedom that will warm 1,000 generations to come. That's my dream, anyway, and as bad as Covid sucked for nearly everyone, I'm thankful we are now sure that changing established science without so much as a discussion doesn't make sense; nor does the fact that it happened go away without talking about it. We had to re-learn the "verify" part of trust as "Wisdom" insists is prerequisite, but once we verify as the new rule, what even could stop us from being #Freeatlast, as we are promised as a people? Beyond our borders, the general state of affairs around the world for the past 3 years taught the regular people, for the final time, that our systems of government are not doing what was purported in establishing them, viz. to do the most good for the most people possible, and because there remains no doubt, nor any doubt relative to why America didn't face as much Tyranny, esp. in rural areas, as did every other country in the World. We believe every man woman and 18 year old person "ought to" have a gun, and to be trained in its safe use, respect for its power, and security that such a tool provides in the right hands. Change will be much more accepted when our government actually seeks to resolve the trauma it's inflicting on our people, instead of just sending out the bomb squad with the fire hose when we show up too frequently or too loudly.

    *'Welcome to Our blog*! I say ours, because even if I don't get elected, I will look to maintain this blog and comment section as a hub for community interaction independent of the more restrictive "commonplaces," for the obvious reasons that go along with "unpopular" geopolitical opinions, even when only unpopular because of the ways certain American fundamentals threaten to interrupt runaway predatory capitalism, as they were designed to. Capitalism with a conscience is America, social security, medicare, community involvement, etc.,  and because none of us actually needs to be told what happens if we act like "it" didn't matter, for 70 years; as we're living it every day; that knowledge has a chance to make the "common senses" "sophisticated" in a way that will carry us to heights we can't yet even imagine. All are welcomed in such a Party, and in my particular campaign, especially those who didn't think so. Reason having dicted the same, we will not be Right nor Left, as a house divided against itself can not stand, and we will seek to be the best possible bargain for all of us, to the extent our minds can determine how to accomplish it practically. And if I'm elected, as my first campaign promise, please know I'll look to immediately begin work on developing an interactive City outreach program, with free and competent legal counsel, ways to voice concerns or raise proposals for rule changing at the individual (petition) level, and most importantly, a way to learn the law and participate actively in our local government, and especially holding it accountable when it runs a muck. I think it will look something like a combination of Denton411 & Nextdoor combined, through which we could even decide to bring ranked choice voting to a smart phone at our homes, effectively allowing all of us to directly express ourselves in meetings virtually or physically, to the extent we feel so compelled; i.e. commenting in real time, prior to council spending $100 million dollars on a single agenda item in 15 seconds of "deliberation." Lol. That sounds deliberate, alright, and it makes about as much sense to me as does a $300 million dollar city bond package when the city has a $300 million dollar surplus from COVID money and prior bond packages.

    By trade I am a "Jack" of many, and since turning 30 I've primarily been building a residential & light commercial full-service general contracting company and those relationships; and more recently I've been helping take care of my mom who had serious health issues (Stroke) post vaccination, and based in non-optimized parts of our "establishment," which I learned existed in my businesses and teaching career, and out of sheer necessity I began to read the law, now having realized that our "bogeyman" isn't a "suit" in Washington, D.C., and because any TX Home Rule Mayor can sue, and since Denton's council runs the Mayor, we will sue once our people know we need to, in order to have peace. I'm not actively selling real estate because I don't think "leasehold" titles are fair or even technically legal, as Americans are promised "Freehold," but I am very familiar with DFW comings and goings, and I do still occasionally consult as needed. I taught secondary Science and Spanish after college while pursuing professional golf during the summers, and most recently I am candidate for politics locally (Denton City Council).  34 of 36 years of my life I have lived within 10 miles of “the Golden Triangle," “as the crow flies,” the other 2 being 1 year at UT Tyler, and another year Teaching Spanish and Science in the Hill Country (Cherokee ISD).  I've spent the better part of the past 4 years, circa 10,000 unpaid hours at this point, getting myself educated in the law, and “asking” politicians to listen to an “average” man's difficulties. In learning they pretend not to hear for a reason, as a result of non-existent checks and balances / separation of powers in our leadership, meaning a rogue judiciary that doesn't make sense, rather it makes victims, but, I have faced extreme prejudices in the judicial system, which I plan to see resolved so no one else goes through them; and because our law is supposed to “make” “sense,” I believe that's why we were trained away from understanding it, or even reading it at all.

    For these reasons I started saying the quiet part out loud, about 2 years before it became popular or even acceptable to do so, but in the ways I talk about these and other “off-limits” topics like “why are y'all saying bribery is legal, just as long as you call it something else (lobbying)?” If the Constitution says the “juries shall be directed by the courts to decide the law and the facts…” would that keep the power to determine the way our laws walk the streets with the people, as opposed to the “cult's opinion" being what decides everyone's laws, as is true today? Judges and Attorneys “opine” about the intent of other judges and attorneys, who are somehow serving in the Legislative and Executive branches while aslo officers of the courts, thus swearing allegiance to us, God, and freedom knowing they could never do that job “justly?", and they don't understand the conflicting interests there? To quote one of my favorite attorneys, “Ignorantia non excusat,” and their decision to betray the Supreme Law of the Land always carried with it reproof. For example, how long would it take us to end qualified immunity, and for that matter all immunity (judicial, legislative, prosecutorial, etc.), if a jury of Uvalde parents were brought an indictment of since-fired “Chief" Pete Arredondo? “Your honor, the deliberation took 15 minutes, because we ordered starbucks. He is definitely guilty of perjury of the oath he swore to God and to us to do his job, especially considering that oath is proscribed to be taken "in the mode most binding upon the conscience, subject to the pains and penalties of perjury. As the attorneys have driven the North American huddled masses off a cliff, on purpose, that is certainly a betrayal of the fiduciary duty (they have in accepting money from us for that).

    If at the time the Constitution was written, the betrayal of one's oath, duty, or ruler, esp. of trust, was listed in the dictionary as treason, does it make sense why attorneys are getting to tell juries “you are not to look up what words mean in the dictionary.”? Yikes. Obviously, they don't get ”immunity" while in the same breath as saying they have no “implied duty to defend” the general public. That's nonsensical, and if I'm elected, I will put Denton's issues on the agenda, instead of just “Denton Proper,” as it has catered to in recent history, and make sure the rest of our politicians understand their oaths mean they don't have a choice other than to render aid, when necessary.

    Of the most blatantly contemptuous responses I've heard was when I asked Councilwoman Vicki Byrd last June, “how is it that y'all seem to defy the Constitution(s) so boldly and so comfortably, though you swore to God you would uphold them (State and Federal) and her reply was, ”the way I understand it, we can do whatever we want."

    I went to them with proof of $250 Billion (yes, with B) in fraud per year in the property casualty insurance business, where regulators are helping insurers artificially inflate premiums, then raking in the record profits at the expense of the American consumer. The loss inland is obviously much less to deal with than total losses of homes in record hurricanes and flooding, and our political establishment doesn't seem to want to do anything about any of it? Is that because of Citizens united v FEC and the whole “bribery” thing? Do you want the answers to these questions to be decided openly and fairly, as America was designed to do? Vote for me and I'll give it my everything to make sure that happens before the year is up.
